text: All right, cool.

Well, I really appreciate
the opportunity

to speak at the Stanford
Robotics Seminar.

It's really cool
as a PhD student.

I'm sure some will agree
to be able to share

our research with folks here
at Stanford and folks watching
at home.

So today, I'm excited to
share some of my research

during my PHD, which
proposes the idea that

wearing a virtual reality
headset while driving a car

could potentially help us
improve vehicle safety.

And I like to start with
a quick introduction.

I want to show some
of my colleagues

who I've gotten to work
with throughout my PhD.

So I'm a student in
the Dynamic Design Lab.

It's a group in
mechanical engineering led

by Professor Chris
Gerdes and we do a lot
of testing on real vehicles.

This is one of our
test vehicles here.

And the lab focus is really on
enhancing safety on the road

by doing different research
projects on vehicle
dynamics and control.

We've done a lot of
work looking at vehicles

at and beyond the
friction limit.

So we've done work autonomously
racing and drifting vehicles.
And my particular interest is--

Mark had pointed out
in the introduction,

is on automotive human
machine interaction.

So I'm really interested in
designing driver assistance

systems that work with
and around human drivers.

And one of the scenarios
that's motivated my work

is a situation that
sometimes occurs

when you're driving
on a back country road

where you may have to
overtake another vehicle.

So imagine you're driving
in that blue vehicle

and you have to
choose the moment

to go from following to
overtaking this vehicle.

And this is a potentially
dangerous situation, especially

at higher speeds and
with another vehicle
coming in the oncoming lane.

So I'd really like
to think about how

to design a driver assistance
system to support drivers
in such a scenario.

And one promising
paradigm that we've

been looking at in our group is
what's called shared control.

So it's the idea of a
system that can blend inputs
with the driver.

So rather than just
taking over control

and then handing it back to the
driver later, it's something--

a simple example
of shared control

would be like a
lane center assist

system that provides little
nudges on your steering wheel
to help you track the lane.

But I'm interested in
extending these systems
to much more complex scenarios.

And a question that
has come up in thinking

about how to design a
system is, how might we

test novel shared
control architectures

in safety critical scenarios
with other road users?

And this has turned out to be
sort of a challenging problem

because in order to show
that our system works well,

we want to run lots
of tests of it.

And some of the
challenges that arise

when thinking about how to test
shared control architectures

are that we know
that drivers rely

on a lot of different sensory
cues to control their vehicle.

For example, the
feeling of the motion

of the vehicle that people
sense with their vestibular

system in their inner ears,
as well as haptic feedback

they get from the steering
wheel and the pedals.

We also would like
to validate systems

that we design across a variety
of test conditions and ideally,
on a real vehicle.

Well, doing testing on a
real vehicle at a test track

can be expensive and
we're often limited
by the space of the track.

And it can also be dangerous
to run experiments, obviously,
with other road users.

So the solution
that I will suggest,

as the title of my
talk sort of proposes,

is to immerse the
driver of a real vehicle
in a virtual driving scene.

This is something known
as Vehicle-in-the-Loop.

And I'm not the first person
to think of this idea.

In fact, this was first proposed
all the way back in 2007

by some really talented
engineers at Audi that

built a system where you
have a driver in a real car

and they're wearing an
augmented reality headset

and they see virtual lane lines
and virtual other vehicles
in view.

And there have been some
examples of more recent

Vehicle-in-the-Loop systems
using virtual reality.

So this is now where the driver
has no view of the real world.

And this has been used for
various human factors studies

and for driver assistance
system testing, which
is what my real interest is.

And I'll note that so
far, these other platforms

have been limited by the
dynamics of production test
vehicles.

What I mean by this is if you
want to have a vehicle that

handles differently, you know,
go from a Prius to a Tesla

or drive on a different surface,
go from dry pavement to snow,

you need to change
the vehicle or you

need to go to somewhere that
has this different surface.

But we have a really nifty
tool in our arsenal, which

is our test vehicle, X1,
that you've seen also

on the first slide
of this talk, that

was built in our lab
about 15 years ago now,

and we still use it
for testing today.

And it is an all
electric four-wheel steer
by wire vehicle.

And what this means is
four-wheel steering means

we can independently control
all four of the wheels.

So we can have the rear
tires steer as well as
the front tires.

And this allows us to
precisely modify the handling
dynamics of the vehicle.

I'll give a couple
of examples of that.

And it's a steer by wire
system, meaning that handwheel,

that the steering wheel is
not physically connected
to the road wheels.

So we can have a system that
has the road wheels steering

a little bit differently
from the driver.

And we also have a
motor we can put on.

We have a motor that's
attached to the hand wheel that

can give the driver a custom
haptic feedback to give them
different steering feel.

And so one of the early
projects that I did in my PhD

was building a vehicle in
the Loop platform around X1.

So here's a picture of me
wearing a virtual reality
headset.

And as I'm driving
around in the real world,

I am looking at a first person
view inside a virtual vehicle

whose motion corresponds
to the motion of X1

as we can measure it with
high precision GPS sensors.

So let's take a look at what
this looks like in a video.
So I put on my VR headset here.

I'll note that my colleague
Alessandro is just
wearing normal safety goggles.
She actually can see the road.

And we're at a closed test
facility here where we test.

And I've overlaid a virtual oval
track on this rectangular skid
pad area.

Maybe we can turn the video
volume down a tiny bit.

And you can see as I
around the turn here,

we have some cones in
the virtual world that

correspond with cones in
the real world sort of

to demonstrate that even
with the VR headset on,

I can still navigate through
this sort of scenario.

So again, this, what we're
seeing on the main screen here,

is what I'm seeing in the VR
headset while I'm driving.

So as I've discussed, because we
have this flexible vehicle, X1,

we can test in a lot of
different configurations.

So what we just saw was what
I'd call a nominal dynamics
configuration.

This is the current state of
the art in vehicle in the Loop

where we don't modify
the dynamics at all.

I'm just driving the
vehicle manually.

But we can also test in a
low friction environment

and match that up with a low
friction or a snowy scene
in the virtual world.

And this is,
obviously, very useful

because we don't
get a lot of snow

and rain out here in California,
where we do our testing.

And even if we did, X1 has
a lot of exposed wiring.

So I'm not sure we'd want to
get things wet on the car.

And then another
cool thing we can do

is test in a scaled
speed scenario.

So I call this high
speed emulation.

And the idea is we
can scale up the speed

of the virtual
vehicle, so we can

run tests at, say, 60 miles per
hour on a limited track area.

And now, I'll give a
little bit more information

on how the low friction and the
high speed configurations work.

So low friction
emulation is a concept

that was introduced by a former
lab member, Holly Russell,
about 10 years ago.

And it's an idea
to get the vehicle

to handle as if it's on
a snowy or icy surface.

And the way that it works is,
we take the driver's inputs

and pass them through a
reference dynamics model.

So we calculate, we simulate
the motion of the vehicle

as if it were on
a snowy surface,

say, with a friction
coefficient of 0.3.

That's the friction coefficient
between tires and snow or snow
and ice.

And then we can calculate
what the yaw rate are.

That's the rotation
of the vehicle.

The longitudinal velocity
Ux, the lateral velocity Uy
would be in this snowy surface.

And then we can track these
three velocity states on X1

on a high friction surface
using the four-wheel steering
capabilities of X1.

In this case, the
controller tends

to make the rear wheels steer
in the opposite direction

of the front
wheels, and it gives

this sort of exaggerated
yaw motion that

simulates the feeling of
fishtailing on snow and ice.

And then something that I've
done, part of my work in my PhD

has been building on
this and creating what
I call high speed emulation.

And this is something
that specifically

takes advantage of having the
VR headset in the vehicle.

And the idea is to scale up the
speed of X1 in the virtual world
by a constant factor.
In practice, a factor of 2 or 3.

And then in this case,
we're interested in tracking

the lateral acceleration in
yaw rate on the real vehicle

so that the driver gets
the sensation of motion

that they would expect in
their vestibular system

while they're making lane
changes at this higher speed.

So what this looks like is,
if in the virtual world,

the virtual vehicle is going at
60mph and the driver is taking,

say, a somewhat aggressive turn
at 0.5 G's of acceleration,

we can exactly track that
acceleration and yaw rate,

or get close to exactly tracking
that, with a controller that,

in this case, tends to steer
the rear wheels in the same
direction as the front wheels.

So X1 has this kind of
exaggerated crabbing motion that

gives that feeling of
lateral acceleration

that one would expect
at a much higher speed.

And I'd like to show a little
bit of data from one experiment

to show how the
controller works.

So the top plot here
is the yaw rate.

Middle plot is the
lateral acceleration.

Bottom plot are
steering angles, delta.

And in the top plot, we
can see that the real yaw

rate on the vehicle tracks the
reference signal, in orange,

within human
perception thresholds.

So we can look at various
human factor studies that

suggest as a conservative value,
maybe 2 to 3 degrees per second

is the minimum threshold of yaw
rates between which people can't
discriminate the difference.

We also see that the lateral
acceleration on the real vehicle

tracks the reference value
and adds this sort of higher
frequency content on top of it.

And that's actually
reflecting the vibrations

of the real vehicle, which is
something that helps further
immerse the driver.

And it also is something
that moving platform driving

simulators that
maybe folks have seen

before at car companies
that kind of slide

the driver around can sometimes
struggle with these vibrations.
But we get those for free in X1.

And then at the
bottom plot, it shows

in the orange and
yellow dashed lines

how the steering angles tend to
track each other to both track

the yaw rate and the lateral
acceleration together.

So as I mentioned up front,
the real purpose of this

is to develop shared
control systems that

can help drivers in
difficult driving situations.

So now I want to provide
a little bit of detail

on a shared control system
that we've used and tested
in these different settings.

So what I'm going
to present here

is what's called a receding
horizon shared control system,

it's also known as model
predictive control, where

we can measure the vehicle's
state at the current time step.

And then project out over
the next three seconds

with a series of discrete
states where the vehicle

may be and basically, solve for
a trajectory over that three

second horizon that optimizes
for different parameters

and use that to share
control with the driver.

So the idea here is we want
the system, in this case,

to try and track the driver's
inputs on the steering,
the throttle and the brakes.

But we allow the system
to intervene as necessary

using steer by wire and throttle
and brake by wire on the vehicle

to help keep the vehicle
within road boundaries

to avoid other vehicles, in
this case in the virtual world,

and also to do this
while respecting coupled

lateral and longitudinal
vehicle dynamics.

And I'll note that
this controller

is based on work from one of
my colleagues, John Talbot.

And now, I'd like to show
a couple of experiments

with this controller running
in these different conditions.

So a low friction experiment
and a high speed experiment.

So let's imagine we want to
test how the controller performs

in supporting a driver on
a hairpin turn on an icy
surface or a snowy surface.

But we only have access
to this dry pavement road.

You can actually
verify that it's

sort of a sunny day by looking
at how brown the grass is
around the track.

So this is at the same facility
from the earlier video.

Our lab goes to Thunderhill
Raceway to test our vehicles.

And this is turn 10
on the West track.

And we can turn this into
our snowy hairpin experiment

by putting our test vehicle
with this low friction emulation
overlaid on the track.

So now what you'll
see in this video

is the snowy virtual world that
I'm seeing in virtual reality,

as well as you can note that the
car is emulating low friction
dynamics.

And also one thing I didn't
explicitly talk about,

but that is part
of this experiment,

is the steering feel
on X1 has been modified

to reflect the lower forces
that one would expect
to feel while driving on snow.

And then you'll see
these dots visualized

for the driver, the MPC horizon,
the horizon of the controller.

And then we can also take a look
at how the system intervenes
to keep the driver safe.

So in blue is the driver
steering angle, and in red

is actually the roadwheel angles
that sometimes differ in order
to keep the driver on the road.

So we'll start the
experiment here again.

I'll emphasize it's
a dry, sunny day,

but to me, driving
this car, I feel

like I'm in Chicago in
the middle of winter.

And we can evaluate
the performance
of this shared control system.

So we can see that it kind of
tracks my steering at first.

And then I'll try to steer
off the road to the left here,

the system steers me
back to the right.

Going into the turn,
the car is actually

slowing down a little bit to
keep you from sliding out,

since this is an emulated,
low friction environment.

And then again, I'll try
to steer off the road.

The system will
help catch me here.

And one really cool
thing about this work

is that this was sort of
part of the development

process for my colleague
John's shared control work.

And we then took
this controller,

he was able to then take
the insights from testing

this controller and this
emulated low friction surface

over to a winter
testing facility

that we test at in
Sweden and actually

run this controller
on real snow and ice.

So this sort of shows that
these sorts of techniques

can provide a nice intermediate
test bench between simulation

and the very expensive
trip to Sweden

that requires flights and
testing on an actual snowy
surface.

So we'll now return to
the motivating scenario

that I was interested in for
the second experiment, which is
a highway overtaking scenario.

And here we'll see a
shared control system

that helps the driver overtake
the lead vehicle while getting

back onto the road before the
oncoming vehicle gets to them.

And I'll emphasize
that the skidpad, which

is just a big
rectangular parking

lot that we test
at at Thunderhill,
only gives us maybe 200 meters.

In reality, like 180 meter
with safety bounds to test on.

But if we scale the speed
up of the virtual vehicle

and kind of overlay
that on the track,

we can run an experiment
at much higher speeds

and safely run this
test on the track

while the driver gets all of
the vestibular haptic visual

feedback that they would
expect at this higher speed.

So let's see a
similar video here.
You'll see the MPC horizon.

You'll see the system
sort of intervening.

And I'll note that
the real vehicle, X1,

in the upper right corner is
only driving at 1/3 the speed
of the virtual vehicle.

So I'll start the test here
and the scaled speed technique

quickly gets me up to a speed
where we can turn on the driver
assistance system.

And then the system
sort of finds
a gap between the two vehicles.

It's actually giving me
a little throttle there

and it steers me to the right
to avoid that oncoming vehicle.

And then I try to
steer off the road

and it helps keep me on the
road again, the virtual road.

Well, you can see we're
well within the confines
of the real world here.

I'll play this
video one more time

so we can take another look
since it's kind of quick.

And I'll emphasize that this
is the type of experiment that

would be way too dangerous to
run with other real vehicles
and/or at these speeds.

But with our vehicle in the Loop
platform and scaling the speed

up, we can give the driver a
somewhat frightening experience,

but still have them
drive safely and see

how it feels to drive with some
sort of novel shared control
technology.

And what we saw here is
an example of a system

that sort assumes that the
driver wants to shoot the gap.

What I don't really have
time to talk about today,

but has been the second
part of my PhD work

has been building on this
to develop controllers

that can help drivers make
decisions between following

the lead vehicle
versus overtaking

and make lane changes
on the highway.

But the point here is
really to demonstrate

that we can test these
sorts of systems safely

and in a very immersive and
evocative driving platform.
So a few takeaways from today.

Vehicle-in-the-Loop, which
is wearing a VR headset while

driving, can provide a balance
of realism and practicality
for shared control testing.

And specifically, designing our
Vehicle-in-the-Loop platform

around a four-wheel steer by
wire vehicle like X1 can enable

us to test in
various conditions.

And in my mind, we
now have the tools

to develop assistance systems
that can help drivers navigate
the road more safely.

Because that's really the
ultimate goal of this,

to use this as a tool to
develop better driver assistance
systems.
So thank you.

And I'm now ready to
take your questions.
[APPLAUSE]
Yeah?

What's the maximum
rear steering angle

that you guys achieve
on this vehicle?
It can go up to 33 degrees.
Yeah, it helps a lot.

The front steering angle is
constrained to 18 degrees,

so when we're trying to, like,
load the car into the truck

or drive around the
track, we almost always

turn on the four-wheel
steering so we can actually
maneuver it around.

But that's thanks to the
work of several colleagues

that predated me that
built a really nice--

You can't quite see it
on the picture here,

but a really nice rear
suspension and steering geometry

to get these really
big steering angles.
Yeah?

So like when you are relating
the low friction scenario,

because when you are
actually accelerating,

the acceleration of the
vehicle would be lesser

in the snow because
of lower friction.

Like, in the real world,
it would be higher.

So how are you trying to
emulate that particular thing.
Yeah.

That way, you couldn't
be just matching

the speed of the test vehicle
speed and the emulated vehicle

speed they will just match or
the longitudinal acceleration
will just match?
Yeah, that's a good point.

I can actually go
back to that slide.

I think implicit
in this slide here

where I discuss low friction
emulation is the idea that if we

can track these three
velocity states,

so that basically
the three velocities

that define the planar
motion of the vehicle,

then this also enables us
to track the accelerations

because the lateral and
longitudinal acceleration

of using a planar
vehicle dynamics model

is just the
derivative of Uy or Ux

plus another term that accounts
for the rotational component
of acceleration.
That's r times either Uy or Ux.

And basically, if we're
tracking these three velocities,

then we would expect to
get the same accelerations

on the real vehicle
than one would
expect while driving on snow.

So for example, if I just punch
it, if I step on the throttle

and try to go as
fast as I can, I

will only get the
longitudinal acceleration

that I would get
on the low friction
surface on the real car.
Does that makes sense?
Any other questions?
Yeah?

Hi, I'm curious, when you
think about shared autonomy?

To what extent can it tell you
you're not allowed to do that?

What I saw in that
video, you were

trying to go out of the
lane and it kept you there.

Do you think in the
future there should

be things that fully don't
let you take actions that you
want to take as a driver?
Yeah, this is a big question.

This is like one
of the big things

that I've been thinking
about, and I don't really
have a complete answer to it.

I think one thing that we
found with this controller

that we saw in the video is
it can feel a little bit--

you feel like you're
taken out of the loop

as a driver when you go
to steer off the road.

And then suddenly without
any feedback or anything

at all, the car just
kind of bumps you back.

It can also feel kind
of cool that the car

is catching you in this way
and is helping keep you safe.

I think haptic feedback
on the steering wheel,

which is something I
worked on in later versions

of the controller,
is really important.

And then another
big aspect of this

is, if we start thinking
about this as not just shared

control, but shared
decision making and control

and deciding between
different maneuvers,

we have to think
about who's really

making the decision of
what maneuver to do.

And one of the tools that
I've used in my research
is actually a design metaphor.

And I think about designing
a driver assistance

system in the context
of partner dancing.

Actually, that's something
that I'll talk about
in my thesis defense.

And the idea is we imagine
the driver as the lead

and they're guiding the
system as the follow
through sequences of maneuvers.

Then we have a bit
of an asymmetry

between the driver
and the system,

which can help disambiguate
who is in charge of what

aspects of decision
making and control.

But this is still like
a big open question

and a lot of my
researchers are, you know,

trying to come up
with the best answers.
Yeah?

Maybe this would be more
appropriate for training people.

You could come up with a
modulation of this that
helps people be better drivers.
Yeah.

And then they-- and
then you wouldn't

have to answer all
these thorny questions.
[CHUCKLES]

And also, I mean, I
think you can only
take headsets so long, right?
[CHUCKLES]
That's been my experience.

Oh, as in you get motion sick
from having it on for too long?

Well, just lots
of things, right?

It seems if you had something
where you could actually

do a heads-up-display
in a car, then

people would be
happy with whatever.
But--
Yeah, yeah, yeah.

Well, I would not suggest at all
that we have real drivers wear
VR headsets on the real road.

And I also wouldn't
really suggest

that we have passengers
wear VR headsets either

because I just think too
much time in VR in general
is bad in many ways.

And the heads-up-display
can definitely

give certain bits of
information to the driver,

like the trajectory
and the deviation
that the system is planning.

Specifically for this work,
the VR headset is really nice

because we can totally
block out the real world,

so the driver feels like
they're in this sort

of alternate reality and
they get the motion cues

that match that, which kind
of helps with the simulator
sickness.

But I agree with a
lot of the points.

And might this also not
have more application

early on in training
race drivers?
Yeah.

People that are in really
extreme situations.
Yeah, definitely.

I think training is a big,
big focus area for this.

And I know, for example,
to get a driver's license

or to be able to

in a lot of European
countries, because there's

a lot of snow in a lot of
Northern and central Europe,

people have to go to actual
ice facilities and practice,

you know, keeping the car from

So my collaborators
in Europe have

they've done.

And I think this can be

So I totally agree.

You don't have any
